reviewText: This a pretty interesting based-on-a-true life-story of hot-rod racer Shirley Muldowney. Bonnie Bedalia plays the woman who was a pioneer of her sorts, becoming the first female star in thay sport. Whether her life was one big soap opera, I don't know, but the movie concentrates on that sort of thing.Shirley had to fight a lot of obstacles to become the first female star of drag racing. However, the constant arguments with her husband (a very profane Leo Rossi) and then with crew chief-former lover Connie Kallitta (Beau Bridges) wore thin after awhile.**spoiler alert**  One very, very memorable scene in here: Muldowney on fire, stumbling down the racetrack after her car caught on fire. That was horrifying and a scene I've never forgotten, and I first saw this over 20 years ago. Other that that, it's a so-so story and better than so-so if you don't let the language bother you.

reviewText: My husband bought this because he wanted me to see how women became involved in driving professionally. It was just okay for me but I am not a huge drag racing fan. I would of given less stars but I do like movies based on life experiences. Shirley is a rock and overcame many obstacles for herself and helped paved the way for other women.

reviewText: While I admire her Racing ability and the movie sure depicts that,I do not admire her private personal life,Yes Her First Husband what he did was not Right but how can you leave behind a Son?"If you Need anything Call Grandma"..yes later he worked for her,And then go off with a Talented yet Creep Like Connie? Her life would have been alot more interesting if she had more morals,The racing footage is good And the Early 50s Drags as well As the Corvette,But This whole WomenLib/Fem/PostFeminist mumbo jumbo cannot take away the fact you would leave a Kid behind for Ambition,I dont care if your a Woman,Man,Green or blue. Anyways my favorite Feminist is Phyllis Schafly. the movie is worth watching but she ain't no hero.

reviewText: Shirley Muldowney thanks to Big Daddy Don Garlits entered the world of racing back when women were not allowed on the track unless they were the beauty queen waiting to give out the trophies. Heart Like a Wheel tells about how Muldowney and her racing career.Heart Like a Wheel is well-written, the acting is superb, and I presume reasonably accurate. For example in one scene you'll here the infamous "S...U...N...D...A...Y used to advertise racing events in Southern California back in the 70s to 80s, if I remember right.Highly recommend.MR
Title: N/A

reviewText: Like most Hollywood biographies this one takes some liberties with the facts but even saying that,  this is one of the best auto racing films ever made.  Maybe I'm jaded a little because my love of the early years of drag racing.  This film brings back vivid memories of my own days at Fremont Drag Strip in California,  a track like so many others that has been torn out and lost forever.  Lion's in Long Beach,  Half Moon Bay, the list goes on and on and all have been lost, never to return.  This movie gives us old Gear Heads a little rise and it's also a great and true story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was thrilled to see this on DVD. Such a great story with top notch acting. A real story about real people. An added bonus to see the interviews of Shirley and Big Daddy. A great inspiration to all!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm proud to say I've known Shirley for 40+years.If anyone deserved a Bio flick was this headstrong woman. I photographed her first big time Funny Car and then I photographed it when she burned it to the ground at West Salem,Ohio.She was back the next day at the racetrack with her bandages covering her serious burns and talking about rebuilding and getting ready for the next race. That's what kind of racer Shirley was and is a fighter in Funny Car class and a true Champion in the Top Fuel Dragster class. This movie is a bit hokey but it really shows Shirley's struggle to become The 1st Lady of the Quarter Mile and I'm glad she's a friend of mine.
summary: A Great Drag Racing movie about my old pal Shirley Muldowney
